198.title: Supervised Group Study for Undergraduates
198.description: Supervised cooperative study of topics (in Slavic and East European languages and literatures) not covered by regularly scheduled courses.

98.title: Directed Group Study
98.description: Group study of selected topics not covered by regularly scheduled courses.

310.title: Internship in the Teaching of Literature/Linguistics
310.description: Weekly meetings with the instructor of the designated course. Discussion of course aims, syllabus preparation, lecture and assignment planning, grading, and related matters. Students may prepare a representative portion of the work for such a course (e.g., lecture outline and assignments for a course segment) and may participate in presentation of the material and in evaluation of samples of student work.

298.title: Special Study for Graduate Students
298.description: Preliminary exploration of a restricted field involving research and a written report.

222.title: Descriptive Grammar of Slavic Languages
222.description: Survey of morphology and syntax of a contemporary Slavic language (Czech, Polish, Russian, or Serbian/Croatian); see departmental announcement for topic. Recommended for prospective teachers.

200.title: Graduate Colloquium
200.description: Reports on current scholarly work by faculty and graduate students.

R5A.title: Reading and Composition
R5A.description: Reading and composition course based on works of Russian and other Slavic writers, either written in English or translated into English. As students develop strategies of writing and interpretation, they will become acquainted with a particular theme in Russian and/or Slavic literatures and their major voices. R5A satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R5B satisfies the second half.

280.title: Studies in Slavic Literature and Linguistics
280.description: Advanced studies in the several fields of Slavic literatures and linguistics. Content varies.

239.title: Twentieth-Century Slavic Literary Theory
239.description: Attempts to describe literary forms, poetic usage of language, and cultural infrastructure, as a code, examined as a consistent trend in 20th-Century literary theory. Consideration of this scholarly trend in historical perspective; its sources, evolution, and eventual dissipation.

H195.title: Honors Seminar
H195.description: Study and research on a topic selected by the student in consultation with the faculty adviser, to culminate in the writing of a thesis. See departmental description of the Honors Program.

134C.title: Dostoevsky
134C.description: A survey of the writer's principal artistic works, treated in relation to his life and to developments in Russian and European literature. Extensive outside reading required for this course.

134E.title: Chekhov
134E.description: Studies in the innovative master of modern narrative forms: short story, drama, letter. Extensive exposure to the life and times of Anton Chekhov. Practice in critical approaches to literature and theater. Writing-intensive course.

158.title: Topics in East European/Eurasian Cultural History
158.description: This course examines various dimensions of different East European and Eurasian (Central Asia, the Caucasus, Siberia) cultures (history, society, languages, literature, art). Variable topics. Instruction and readings in English; students with knowledge of the languages of the area are encouraged to do some reading in the original language.

299.title: Directed Research
299.description: Normally reserved for students directly engaged upon the doctoral dissertation.

375A.title: Teaching Methods for Slavic Languages
375A.description: Course on practical teaching methods, grading, testing, and design of supplementary course materials. Required of all graduate student language instructors in Slavic. Course to be repeated for credit each semester of employment as a graduate student instructor.

256.title: Topics in Slavic Folklore
256.description: Selected topics in Slavic folklore, with focus on contributions to folklore theory based on Slavic material.

R5B.title: Reading and Composition
R5B.description: Reading and composition course based on works of Russian and other Slavic writers, either written in English or translated into English. As students develop strategies of writing and interpretation, they will become acquainted with a particular theme in Russian and/or Slavic literatures and their major voices. R5A satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement, and R5B satisfies the second half.

190.title: Russian Culture Taught in Russian: Country, Identity, and Language
190.description: Based on a wide range of sources from the 19th and 20th centuries--works of fiction, publicistics, personal documents--the course will trace the formation and historical transformation of Russian cultural identity, including issues in national identity, ethnicity, position in relation to state, gender, and sexuality. The class is aimed at students with advanced knowledge of Russian, both Americans studying Russian and Russians living in America. All readings, lectures, and discussions in Russian.

375B.title: Teaching Methods of Reading and Composition
375B.description: Course on practical teaching methods, grading, testing, and design of supplementary course materials. Required of all graduate student instructors in Slavic. Course to be repeated for credit each semester of employment as a graduate student instructor.

133.title: The Novel in Russia and the West
133.description: Study of major Russian and Western (European and American) 19th- and 20th-century novels, and their interrelations. Variable reading list. See Department announcement for description.

138.title: Topics in Russian and Soviet Film
138.description: This course will examine the Russian contribution to film history and theory, with particular attention paid to the role of the cinema in Soviet culture and Russian films complex ties to literary and political movements. Variable topics.

50.title: Introduction to Russian/East European/Eurasian Cultures
50.description: This course introduces students to the cultures of the peoples of the former Soviet bloc (Russia and other areas of the former Soviet Union, including Central Asia and the Caucasus, and Eastern Europe), from early times to the present, with the emphasis on cultural identity. Readings in history, fiction, folklore, viewing of films, and art works. Thematic units include: formation of the Russian civilization, Slavic nationalism in the Romantic era, empire and identity in Eastern/Central Europe; Soviet and post-Soviet daily life, Jews in Slavic lands, the former Yugoslavia; multi ethnic lands. Required of majors in Russian/East European/Eurasian cultures, the course is also aimed at a broad audience. Knowledge of the languages of the area is not required.

46.title: Twentieth-Century Russian Literature
46.description: Development of Russian literature from 1900 to the present: modernism, Soviet, and <emigre> literature. No knowledge of Russian required. Prerequisite to admission to the Slavic major and recommended for prospective graduate students.

99.title: Individual Study
99.description: Supervised independent study for lower division students with a minimum 3.0 GPA.
